title: Michelle Steel
added: Steel has generated controversy for speaking at a Tea Party event in [[Newport Beach, California|Newport Beach]] about withdrawing her younger daughter from the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]] and sending her to [[Loyola Marymount University]] for a one-year "brainwash" after her daughter voiced support for [[same-sex marriage]] and [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|date=July 8, 2020|title=California GOP congressional candidate claimed she withdrew her daughter from college for supporting gay marriage|url=https://www.metroweekly.com/2020/07/california-gop-congressional-candidate-claimed-she-withdrew-her-daughter-from-college-for-supporting-gay-marriage/|accessdate=August 21, 2020|website=Metro Weekly}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=|first=|date=July 7, 2020|title=Republican congressional candidate bragged about pulling daughter out of university for ‘brainwashing’ after she supported equal marriage|url=https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2020/07/07/michelle-steel-california-orange-county-republican-daughter-university-santa-cruz-equal-marriage/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|accessdate=August 21, 2020|website=PinkNews}}</ref>

title: Michelle Steel
added: [[Category:Asian-American members of the United States House of Representatives]]

title: Michelle Steel
added: The [[San Francisco Chronicle]] speculated that Steel, along with Young Kim and Mike Garcia could be potential Republican candidates to challenge Democratic Senator [[Alex Padilla]] in the [[2022 United States Senate election in California|2022 Senate election]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Wildermuth|first=John|date=2020-12-29|title=Can California GOP find a Senate candidate in 2022? If not, Alex Padilla could be set for years|url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/politics/article/Can-California-GOP-find-a-Senate-candidate-in-15832834.php|access-date=2021-02-08|website=San Francisco Chronicle|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Michelle Steel
added: In March 2021, Steel introduced legislation that would block any federal funding from being used to support [[California High-Speed Rail|California’s high-speed rail project]], which she called a "failure." She specifically said "costs have continued to rise, while people and businesses have lost their properties, the sections of the high-speed rail that do exist are inoperable and this is an unacceptable and an embarrassing waste of taxpayer dollars." Other California Republicans in Congress signed on in support of Steel's bill.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Orange County Republicans take aim at California’s bullet train|work=Orange County Register|url=https://www.ocregister.com/2021/03/01/orange-county-republicans-take-aim-at-californias-bullet-train/|date=March 1, 2021}}</ref>

title: Michelle Steel
deleted: On February 4, 2021, Steel voted against the removal of [[Marjorie Taylor Greene]] of her [[United States House Committee on Education and Labor|House Education and Labor Committee]], and [[House Budget Committee]] assignments in response to controversial political statements she had made.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Clare Foran, Daniella Diaz and Annie Grayer |title=House votes to remove Marjorie Taylor Greene from committee assignments |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/04/politics/house-vote-marjorie-taylor-greene-committee-assignments/index.html |publisher=CNN |access-date=5 February 2021}}</ref>

title: Michelle Steel
added: On February 27, 2021, Steel joined with all Republicans to vote against the [[American Rescue Plan Act of 2021]], a $1.9 trillion COVID-19 relief bill, citing a lack of bipartisanship, the raising of the minimum wage which would cost jobs, adding on to the national debt, and criticizing the bill for only having 9 percent of the funding directly going towards combating COVID-19. She cited President Trump's previous efforts to obtain relief for COVID-19 in Congress, and how the majority of that money remained unspent.<ref>{{cite press release |last=Kim |first=Young|date=27 February 2021|title= Rep. Steel: “Relief should be targeted, temporary and tied to COVID” |url=https://steel.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-steel-relief-should-be-targeted-temporary-and-tied-covid |location=Washington, DC }}</ref>
